qas.question: In what year did Shell and Cosan form a 50:50 joint venture?
What was the name of the 50:50 joint venture formed by Shell and Cosan?
Why did Shell sell some of its assets in March 2010?

answers.text: to meet the cost of a planned $28bn capital spending programme

qas.question: How much did Shell plan to raise from the sale of its assets?
Royal Dutch Shell agreed to acquire all the business of what entity in June 2010?
Who did Shell split with in 2010?
When did Shell form a joint venture with Raizen?
How much were the East Resources' gas fields worth?
How much was Shell's liquid petroleum gas business worth?

plausible_answers.text: all the business of East Resources

qas.question: What did Shell buy from Cosan for $4.7 million?

context: In February <a0_0><b6_0>2010<b6_0/><a0_0/> Shell and <b5_0>Cosan<b5_0/> formed a 50:50 joint-venture, <a1_0>Raízen<a1_0/>, comprising all of Cosan's Brazilian ethanol, energy generation, fuel distribution and sugar activities, and all of Shell's Brazilian retail fuel and aviation distribution businesses. In March 2010, Shell announced the sale of some of its assets, including its liquid petroleum gas (LPG) business, <a2_0>to meet the cost of a planned <b8_0>$28bn<b8_0/> capital spending programme<a2_0/>. Shell invited buyers to submit indicative bids, due by 22 March, with a plan to raise <a3_0>$2–3bn<a3_0/> from the sale. In June 2010, Royal Dutch Shell agreed to acquire <b9_0>all the business of <a4_0>East Resources<b9_0/><a4_0/> for a cash consideration of <b7_0>$4.7 billion<b7_0/>. The transaction included East Resources' tight gas fields.
